resources.string: Owing to wealthy history, Legnica became an old city with unique atmosphere. Above 1000 years of official existence left a great imprint on it’s culture and architecture. During 500 years it was ruled by Piast dynasty. Apart from that it was under rule of Czech dynasty, Habsburgs, Prussia and Germany.

Between 1 June 1975 and 31 December 1998 Legnica became the capital of the Voivodeship. Now it’s the seat of the county and since 1992 it is also the seat of Diocese. Currently about 100000 inhabitants live here. In 1950s and 1960 copper and nickel deposits began to be excavated, changing totally regional economy.
Legnica offers a wide variety od accommodation places for all visitors and all budgets. Situated mainly within the center area of the city will satisfy almost everyone.

There’s a great variety of restaurants, pubs or inns in Legnica. There are locals offering typical polish meals and places where you can eat pizza or oriental food. All tastes and budgets will be satisfied.

Legnica is admired for it’s gardens and parks. The city can boast with above 700 hectares of green space which is about 10% of it’s whole surface. In the center of the city there’s a huge 58 hectares park with small palm house and nice pond. Spare time can be also spent on the Kaczawa river banks.

Well communication facilities make Legnica a good place to start trips around region of Lower Silesia. This historical area is full of very interesting places to visit. Below you can find just a few 1 day or weekend trips. However I assure you that there is much more place worth seeing.

First documented historical sources of settlement come from this place about 1850 years ago. A few hundred years later before written evidences – there was a small castle situated in the east part hills. The settlement belonged to the Lusatian culture. In the Romanian times the city was called Lugidunum and existed as the capital of tribe Lugii. It was situated on the antic map of Ptolemy.

Slavic tribes moved into that area around 8th century. Official reference in the cronicles come from 1004. The city name is firstly mentioned in 1149 in the document of High Duke of Poland Boleslaw IV the Curly. Most likely Legnica became his residence. The city started to grow being the fundamental point of trading paths for Europe of Middle Ages.

Legnica became famous city because of the great battle at Legnickie Pole. It was the time of Mongol invasion of Europe. Combined armies of polish duke Henry II the Pious of Silesia, Bavarian miners, Czech troops and military orders were defeated. Mongols killed Henry and destroyed united forces. As a result his coutry collapsed.

At the beginning of 14th century Legnica became the capital of the Duchy. It was one of the most important cities in Central Europe with population reaching almost 16000 inhabitants. Quick growth of the city started after the discovery of gold in the Kaczawa River between Legnica and Zlotoryja. This great city expansion stopped after a huge fire which totally devastated all wooden buildings.

During 14th century Legnica became vassal of the Kingdom of Bohemia and it was absorbed by Holy Roman Empire. Around 1522 the citizens converted into Lutheranism. After the death of King Louis II of Hungary and Bohemia Legnica became the part of the Habsburg Monarchy of Austria.

In 1742 Legnica, along with most of Silesia, became the part of Kingdom of Prussia. It was a result of King Frederick the Great\'s victory over Austria in the War of the Austrian Succession. Seven years’s war bringed in 1760 the great Battle of Legnica where Frederick’s defeated an Austrian army.

In 1813 Prussian army led by Field Marshal Blücher defeated Napoleonic forces in the Battle of Katzbach. By the provisions of Congress of Vienna Legnica and the surrounding territory were absorbed by the Province of Silesia on the 1st May 1816. In 1874 the city became the part of German Empire.
Until 1945 by the provisions of, following Word War I, Treaty of Versailles Legnica became the part of Province of Lower Silesia.

In 1945 Nazi Germany was defeated and World War II was over. Following Potsdam Conference incorporated Legnica and all east Silesia to Poland. German citizens were expelled and replaced with Poles. During the war the city was only slightly demaged. However until 1965 most parts of the old town buildings were destroyed, bringing rebuilt, modern form.

After the World War II Soviet forces in Poland situated headquarters in Legnica. This fact left a great imprint on city’s life. Now it was divided into Polish and Soviet parts. In april 1945 it is etimated that there were about 16000 Polish, 12000 German and 60000 Soviet citizens. Soviets left the city finally in 1993.
Cathedral of Sts. Peter and Paul

Magnificent cathedral was built in 1333 – 1380 and in 15th century the chapels were attached to the side naves. Serious rebuild occurred in 1892 – 94 when the temple received Neogotic style.In 25 March 1992 John Paul II sacrifised it as a cathedral.
The Town Hall was built in neo renaissance style in 1905. Currently it is headquarters of municipality in Legnica.

The building of new theatre was ready on Christmas 1842. It had 500 seat and there were always queues of ticket buyers. After the World War II the theatre was totally destroyed. It started up again in 1977. In 1994 Jacek Glomb began to work as a Chief. His innovative approach brought a great fame in country and on the international field.

The hospital in Legnica was opened in 1989. It’s the largest employer in the city employing over 1100 people. It’s divided into 24 departments with over 600 beds. It services annually over 100000 patients.

A stronghold was erected in 1230s and it was one of the first such castles in Poland. The initiator of the building was Henry I the Bearded. The castle was the residence for the Dukes of Legnica until 1675. It had been rebuilt several times, most significantly by Frederick II. In the 19th century it was reconstructed after a fire. Currently it houses several educational institutions.

It was built in 1728 in Baroque style. It contains the collections associated with excavation, processing and usage of copper. Currently there are over 30000 exhibits and 8200 volumens in the library.

The most probably it was built in 1574. There are 4 renaissance and 4 classical houses. Stylish diversification is the effect of many reconstructions which affected these buildings during next centuries.
It was founded in 1856 and in the beginning lighted about 250 lamps in the city. It had been rebuilt several times, lastly in 1917 when ammonia tower was added.

It has been opened in 1844 and it’s the main station wfor Legnica, being the beginning of the line to Katowice, Jerzmanice-Zdroj and Rudna. It services all kinds of passing trains. Currently it has B category which means that it services annually 1 – 2 milions of passengers.
It was completely rebuiled in 2005. Modernisation brought additional lights, corners, heated turf, full roofing and electronic management and control system.
Cathedral of Sts. Peter and Paul

First written sources about park come as early as from 1316 when duke Boleslaw III bought a huge fields nearby the river. Developed over the years received today\'s outlook. Park is also popular place of sport and cultural events.

It\’s been founded and built in 1898. Palm house has buildings and areas of above 1 hectare. It was badly affected by the flood in 1977. Currently reconstructed and rebuild has free admission for everyone who wants to visit it.
It springs from Kaczawskie Mountains near Kaczorów and flows through region with Legnica until it reaches Oder river where it empties. Total length of the river is 98km (61mi).
It’s a natural monument and historical avenue of London plane. Some trees come from 1844 when the avenue was created. Plants grow to height of 30m and host many species of birds.

It existed as early as in the Middle Ages when was a part of city defence system. Rebuilt over the ages, received today’s outlook in 1929. It was partially destroyed during the flood in 1977. Recultivated in 2008 hosts many interesting plants and animals, mainly birds.

A small town in south – west of Poland, nearby the border with Czech Republic. First written sources about this place come from 1524. Known of mineral water springs. In 1899 great pump-room with spa was built on the hills. It offers mineral water, radon and mud bath treatments of rheumatism. Fans of skiing will like this town for opened in 2008 gondola.

A small town in south – west of Poland, 3km (2mi) from Walbrzych city. First written sources about it come from 1221. Because of many mineral water springs present in the city – pump – room with spa was built in 1820. Horse lovers will find this place attractive because of stud farms.

A small town in south – west of Poland, at the Nysa Szalona River, in the Jawor country. First written sources come from 1276. Known of the Bolkow castle and it’s ruins standing above the town. It was built in 13th century. Devastated by the Thirty Years War.

A small town in south – west of Poland, 14km from Jelenia Gora. First mentioned in 1148. Known of many mineral springs and sanatoriums for different diseases treatment. Fans of toys may note it for expanded miniature park showing architectural monuments of the region.

A large castle located nearby Walbrzych city. Main attraction of the Walbrzych and whole region. First sources about the castle come from 1263. After the World War II used as a sanatorium and cultural place. Currently great part of it is avaiable for sightseeing.

A small and old city in the south – west of Poland, in the Klodzko valey, on the Nysa river. Received city rights in 1233, however first settlements come from as early as at least 1st century BC. Within ages being the part of different countries. Known of large fortress located on the high rock above the city, gothic bridge, tunnels and many more attractions.

A city in south – west of Poland, nearby Karkonosze Mountains. Received the city rights in 1288, being the important part of trade routes in those times. Known of many historical attractions. Fans of sport will find it very attractive for aviation, cycling, canoo or hiking trail activities.

A small town in the south – west of Poland, close to Jelenia Gora city. First written sources come from 1366. Known as a great center of mountain hiking, cycling and skiing. There are also many sanatoriums for different diseases treatment.

Part of Sudetes Mountains, are 42km mountain range. There’s a National Park located at the area of it. Formed mainly of sandstone, contains many strange and interesting rock formations. Very pleasure place for walking.

A nature reserve in the south – west of Poland, on the river Jawornik, part of Jawor county. A reserve was established in 1962. With total area of 9.72 hectare. Famous and attractive walking destination, with a place to lighting up the fire.
